review_title: not a bad place to work but would recommend you check out OSU lab openings
pros: reliable income, occasional bonuses, certainly some nice hard working people to work with. Benefits are average when compared to other healthcare systems in the area. In particular, when I reviewed openings and public salary information for equivalent positions at OSU, pay is relatively higher (about 5-10%)
cons: the main chemistry line(s) broke regularly (1-2x per week on average) and required service to come in, which really backed things up when 10,000+ specimens are coming through daily. A lot of old equipment which needs to be replaced but management often opts to prioritize bringing in other analyzers first in spite of this The IT department situation is terrible since they outsourced the who department overseas, and it makes even simple changes or issues almost impossible to resolve in a reasonable amount of time. I often spent an hour+ on the phone with the new IT group to solve an issue the old IT group (before it was outsourced) could have completed in a about a quarter of the time. During the 4 years I spent there the quality of work life progressively decreased in a variety of ways. I felt as if I showed a lot of initiative and interest in improving my department, but my interest in making a significant contribution was never reciprocated with greater opportunities or practical appreciation

review_title: Great if you’re content with your role and pay
job_title: Medical Laboratory Technician in Columbus, OH
pros: The benefits are slightly competitive.
cons:
If you’re an inexperienced tech, the lack of structure, knowledge/quality of procedures, and laboratory fundamentals amongst employees might be detrimental to your learning as a laboratory professional. Additionally, if you are a knowledgeable and experienced tech, you might find the general apathy frustrating. 

Although there are certainly good employees, overall, there seems to be a culture of willful ignorance, borderline negligence, and a lack of initiative. This might stem from the fact that the company doesn’t give an individual, performance-based, raise. 

Ohio Health, tries to pad their paltry, company-wide, raises with occasional bonuses, usually around $500. If you take your pay seriously, you probably don’t want to stay at Ohio Health. Without market adjustments applied to your pay, getting a 2-3% pay increase annually will leave you grossly underpaid in the long term.

review_title: Strung us along for years with empty promises and bad management
job_title: Protective Services Officer in Columbus, OH
pros: Great co-workers. Amazing training opportunities and insane experience for you law enforcement career. Fast pace and challenging work environment that helps you grow as a LEO.
cons: Empty promises, no respect for the front line Officers, we are just a number. Terrible retirement and health care coverage (over priced for the little you get). High turn over rate due to morale. High amount of serious injuries that you either suck up or you are forced out by doors being closed. Every salary employee is from the outside and these faces change every few years. When the VP is terminated and new one is appointed, everyone is fired and his own team is brought in to lead. Many of whom have ZERO experience in the field and have no idea what you do. Polices get Officers hurt and you are left with almost half of your pay and not able to pay your bills for going into a situation that everyone runs from. You are either liked or your blacklisted and they want to try and ruin your career. Extremely toxic work environment. The only thing that gets you out of bed is not letting your team members down. Does not matter if you work at Grady, Riverside, Grant or Doctors, it is not those teams that make it terrible, it is the management. Again, a management that has never worn that uniform and acts like they have. I would not recommend this agency to anyone, even someone I do not like. If you want to waste some of the best years of your career, go and drink their koolaid. If you want real hospital experience, go to another healthcare system. This system will squeeze every last drop of juice out of the lemon (you) and then leave you on the street with absolutely nothing.

job_title: Senior Financial Analyst in Columbus, OH
pros: Overall, I liked being a part of an organization that continuously tries to make a positive impact in their community, and I had great coworkers.
cons:
Low-pay, very average benefits, and NO opportunity for advancement.  Corporate finance is using very dated technology and systems for financial reporting.  This has also caused some of the turnover issues that the department has seen in both staff and management.  

OhioHealth does not promote from within and prefers to bring in an outside specialist for new positions.  New employees are often overwhelmed by the challenges within the system, and take off sooner rather than later.  This increases the burden on more dedicated long-term employees, who do not see an increase in pay or title for their efforts.  I feel that most of these issues are generated by HR, who do not adequately recruit qualified talent, and only grant promotions based on years of experience, and not by the quality of employee performance.

Managers are often burdened by the framework established by HR and have a difficult time retaining their top talent.

review_title:
Times are changing...

11 year Associate, 2 year Supervisor; 6 month Manager = 13 years and counting.
pros:
OhioHealth goes out of their way to accommodate Associates and provide for their well-being.  Consistent salary increases, bonuses,  401k match, and cash- balance plan, spot bonuses,  free tickets and events, individual and group awards, several fiscount programs, tuition payment and repayment programs,  and a concierge all add up to happy Associates.

Senior leadership has made tremendous strides to engage with Associates and listen and act on feedback. Some of the changes you see at OhioHealth are attributed to the feedback Senior leadership has received. Senior leadership has also empowered the lower level Directors and Managers to act on Associate feedback. Allof this helps create a better patient and Associate experince.
cons:
Change can be hard sometimes.  Healthcare, competition and government regulations are always changing. You either change or get left behind. Those Associates at Ohiohealth that don't change get left behind.  If you don't like change stay out of healthcare. 

Without education, opportunities for growth are limited. I do not gave that education and I am very fortunate to have advanced to a management position.

review_title: Strong Company with Character... A little disorganized
job_title: Applications Systems Consultant in Columbus, OH
pros: I appreciate being able to do work that matters.  At OhioHealth, I'm able to sleep well at night.  My job isn't about bilking the patients for more money.  It's about saving money for the patients and the company, and it's about bringing awareness to patient safety and quality issues.  The pressure is usually not nearly as high as higher paying companies.  Many employees at OhioHealth have been here greater than 15 years.  They are in the top 100 Forbes best places to work for 7 years running.
cons: The company tends to have a re-org quite often.  In my short time at OhioHealth, we've had 3 major re-orgs that affected my role, my position, and my potential advancement.  Salary increases are a flat 2.5% per year. Bonuses are practically nil.

pros:
In this economy and at my age, they have been a stable employer.
If I had the money to move out of the area, I would.
cons: Ever since they took over our small hospital, it's all about money and consolidation. All the top management bailed out shortly before they took over, which should have been a clue as to how they run things. They changed our policies to be less generous, they plan to cut our staff and have done so already. For all their talk of "transparency" they keep us in the dark about their plans pretty much up until it happens. Since they are the major employer in this town, nobody opposes them much anymore. There are a lot of older people that work here and they cannot afford to lose their jobs in this economy.

job_title: Facilities Specialist III in Columbus, OH
pros: Company has above average benifits and pay. Company wants to treat employees like they matter but is a huge a company and employees can be lost in the attempts. Upper level leadership is strong but lower level leadership doesn't really have real management skills, just OTJ experience and falls into leadership roll by longevity.
cons:
Many long tenured employees have no idea what it's like to work for another company and bring morale down with minor complaints that are blown out of proportion. Lower level management have poor skills and rely on harder working employees to do the right thing and take care of problems rather than actually confronting poor performers. Confrontation is non-existent with lower level management, easier for them to stuck head in the sand and ignore issues for as long as possible.

The company loves meeting, even for non-management you can waste a few hours a week in meetings that have no real results.

pros: Pay and benefits are fair. Incentives make health insurance affordable.
cons: A large company swallowing up smaller hospitals statewide. Decisions are made by people far from the bedside who you never see or get an opportunity to talk to. These people keep adding to the pile of job duties for those lower down the chain.  Management models are not individualized for the smaller regional hospitals in their network.

pros: I wish that I could give negative stars.
cons:
An associate at OhioHealth, who left for a new opportunity, was completely ignored by their VP as they were leaving.  That same VP would not shake the associates hand because the associate made a personal decision to pursue a role that better aligns with their career goals.  This is indicative to the no-class operation that has become OhioHealth.  The conduct by senior management is inexcusable and frankly uncalled for.

This is in addition to the two awkward conversations that I have had with vendors about negative comments directed toward me from current senior level staff.  Sadly, I have not uttered a single negative comment about OhioHealth until now.  At this point, I will only share the truth with anyone looking at OhioHealth for a new role and I plan to fully educate my peers within my industry segment about the numerous lies that HR used to get myself to accept the position that I had and unkept promises that were used to keep me in the role.

pros: It's hires new grads so good for entry level to gain experience.
cons:
You ARE a number. 

I was told training would be 6 months it was a year and 6 month.  This was due to meetings, illnesses of trainers, and turn over of trainers.

Extremely high expectations (25 Diagnostic, 18 ER 7 surgery/hr). If you don't meet these standards there is no coaching on how to do so just a email saying if you don't you'll be written up or made to work in house. There is no acknowledgement of when you meet or exceeded the goals.

Very little down time as there is often at least 5hrs of mandatory OT per week often for months.  While I was there they required 15hrs OT over the 2 weeks of Christmas and New Year's. It's very hard to get any answers if PTO is approved due to a high turn over rate of middle management and the miscommunication brought on by it. And you never see upper management.

review_title: Good overall, but a typical big-business healthcare system
pros: Good health benefits, average to good retirement options, once you are in there are a lot of transfer/up-training options if you do it right. Good workers in mostly good locations around Columbus. Lots of small perks (discounts at business for being an OhioHealth employee, lots of holiday celebrations, free meals, small monetary bonuses
cons: Has become very 'big business', focusing on expansion, cost cutting, management restructuring. I witnessed a lot of nepotism, favoritism, & promotions that weren't based on job performance or qualifications. Also witnesses several 'sneaky' layoffs/firings (if you don't make trouble/demands, you are fine, but if you are a problem, they will wait and get rid of you when they see an opportunity to do so without legal consequences).

pros: Company dedicated to serving the community regardless of ability to pay and treating all patients with respect.
cons: Keeping costs down to be able to fund major construction projects and providing free services is apparently what is making employees work with too few staff on the floors and other service areas.  Takes a long time to get updated equipment at the patient care level.  But, they can build a new wing or out-patient facility!  RNs are managing non-nursing staff areas. By controlling a majority market share for the industry, they can pay staff minimum salaries.  Promotions are very rare, if not an RN.  Difficult to get time-off for personal business, such as doctor visits or testing.

review_title: Great Place to Work-if physicians, nurses, and medical technicians’ profession
pros: We do offer unique benefits such as concierge services to all associates so you can have more free time for yourself after work.  Best years as a non-profit in revenue.
cons: Interfacing with the IT organization,  be prepared to be pigeon holed till terminated, finding other work within other teams very limited to non-existent, training only the for the select few, if the current technology does not provide value “hammer  it to a solution to make it fit” mindset.

pros: Like a lot of volunteering work, you get to give back something good to the community. Besides that, you get to network with people within your volunteering environment.
cons: You will have to read the volunteer handbook very carefully to protect yourself especially if you are not medically trained. I have experienced nurses on the floor asking me to change bedsheets of patients (could be highly contaminated) and to enter into the rooms of patients in isolation. If you are thinking of getting a professional recommendation for your work as a volunteer for job search or a job opportunity within the organization, the chances would be very minimal because as soon as you have stopped volunteering, your effort will be dismissed. They are not allowed to provide any professional reference to volunteers because we are not employees of Grant.

pros: Great culture, great people, really care about their employees and get to know them. When I was leaving they were finally adjusting their pay to be more competitive
cons: Salary. I left because of the salary to make $10 more an hour. They're not competitive but it depends on what you are looking for. I could not afford working there and afford my house. I had to get two jobs until I found a new job.  I asked for a raise after being there for 4 years to get $.50. still wasnt enough to live but thats what happens with nonprofits. they will give more money to their executive and an outrageous bonuses to them but not enough for the rest of the team to even manage a house

review_title: pick which campus you work at carefully
pros: fair compensation, well- known hospital system, easy to transfer positions within the company
cons: different campuses and each operates differently (i.e.,work culture, staffing) even though the company stresses "systemness" meaning  all hospital systems should operate the same. They tout their "fortune 500 best company to work for" status but I couldnt figure out what made it one. The "concierge service"that they are so proud of no one ive worked with EVER used.  depending on what campus you work on you may be VERY surprised how it operates so choose wisely and ask about the structure of the floor or department you will work in!!

pros: Ohiohealth is a very reputable company. I had the privilege of working for Marion but hope to move on and work for Riverside in Columbus. They have a  better reputation and doctors that wok there.
cons: It's never easy to see patients that are very ill or have a poor prognosis. We deal with life and death regularly. Those that come in and are coding and do not make it, that's the very sad part of working in emergency care

pros: Shift diff (working night shift) you get an extra 4.75/hr Great teamwork fun group of nurses selfscheduling . Tuition reimbursement for up to 50% with schools ohiohealth partners with.
cons: Insurance is expensive and not very good, have to go to an Ohio health facility 403b.. they combine your age plus number of years you’ve worked with Ohio health so less than 30 they match what you contribute for up to 3% 30-44 4%, 45-59 5%, 60-74 6%, 75 or more 7%

pros: They have good benefits, paid time off is nice, they make the appropriate changes to the “Total Rewards” program when the employees voice reasonable suggestions in surveys.   The pay could be better, but it looks like they are trying to address that in areas.
cons: They are getting very big, very fast.  There is so many large projects and initiatives going on that it’s created chaos and unrest, there is lots of tension developing and staff is not comfortable with such rapid change.   The change is pulling people away from their normal roles and thorough work is being replaced quick fixes.

pros: The benefits are decent. Some of the Nurses are great. There is always a chance for overtime.  I love the 12 hour shifts and being able to have 4-5 days off a week and still be able to have benefits.
cons: Some of the nurses are "too good" to answer call lights even if he/she knows that the patients wants meds.  The PSA is usually extremely busy and still has to answer these call lights and then find the nurse to let them know the patient wants meds. A good majority of the time they are sitting at the nurses station having a conversation about their personal lives.

review_title: Over worked, no one has your back, even with good coworkers there is never enough time to do everything correctly.
pros: Money was pretty good but in the end I hated to come to work. Emergency is just running from fire to fire
cons: Manager said we were just warm bodies and there were 100 applicants for each of our jobs. Days were long and most days no break for 12 hour shift

review_title: Not a good place for nurse practitioners
pros: Good pay and benefits for the area
cons: My manager was an RN with no advanced degree, they promised me a set schedule of 12 hour shifts and instead changed it to 5-8 hour shifts, I already had 3 years experience as an ICU NP with procedures and they privileged me for procedures and then told me I couldn't do any, they don't understand the NP role and treat you like an intern.  It took 4 months to get privileges.

pros: The health insurance benefits are fantastic. Everything is easily accessible online and it's a great company to work for.  They always offer training, mostly since it's mandated, but the fact that it can be done online and in your own time is great.  The people that work there are great as well!
cons: The management on my particular floor could have tried to be more fair.  The night-shift always got a bad rep for things when we were constantly cleaning up messes from day shift (typical day/nigh rivalry I guess) but management didn't view this in a fair manner.  I have heard other floors were better to work on.

review_title: As MGMT is concerned, $$$ is paramount - patients are just numbers.
pros: Good benefits, plenty of training opportunities, nice discounts around central Ohio.
cons: The senior management situation is a nightmare. There is rampant nepotism and favoritism not based on qualifications. The only way to advance is if you buy-in completely. Opposing views are not welcome. Additionally, the environment is so toxic that your directors will hold you back or hide you from sight in order to protect their own jobs and then pass off your work as their own.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Mansfield, OH
pros: I learned something new every time I was floated to another floor.  I had fantastic co-workers.  The assistant nurse manager was fair and easy to communicate to, and she listened.
cons: No yearly cost of living given if on FMLA.  A job could be taken from a person without notice.  Vacation time was taken away without notice.  If you picked up extra time and your time was canceled, you were not given a 24 hour notice, not even a 10 or 5 hour notice.  So you think you have to work and may be getting ready for work and then you are called one hour before your shift.

pros: Benefits, competitive pay, financially successful organization, respected throughout the industry, great for initial management training and resume building.  Learn many things about what not to do when you get the chance to be a Chief.
cons: Golden handshake, climate of fear, loyalty only goes up not down. Everyday could be your last day. Tenure is short term unless you are on the safe side of the ledger.  Status changes virtually everyday depending upon who you displease.

review_title: If you're not a doctor you're nothing

pros: Gained a lot of medical experience
cons: Incompetent Environmental Services management and hospital Administration. Your hard work is never recognized.  If your lazy and don't pull your weight you will be recognized.

review_title: This used to be a great place to work; but not anymore
pros: Amazing coworkers - they get me through the day.  Good perks, e.g. discounted tickets and admissions to various events; discounted prices on goods around central Ohio.  Lots of extra curricular activities to get involved with.
cons: Minimal training before you are thrown to the wolves. Focus has been shifting as of late and it seems to be heading towards a more financially driven focus.  Management makes decisions that affect patient care without asking for input from the staff that deal with the patients all day. Awful work/life balance. High source of stress

pros:
staff were friendly and realistic in comparison to other hospitals. 
Easy to communicate needs with staff. Physicians were approachable and experienced. Fast paced, clean and organized facility.
cons: Salary is mediocre, weekend hour requirements, night shift differential is better elsewhere,  Benefits were average, Manager turn over makes it hard to be recognized or even known. Big corporate healthcare feel even thought they try to make it feel like more connected.

pros: When they say 'Believe in We' they MEAN it.  I have found Ohio Health to be very team focused!   From the moment I walked in the door, they welcomed me as an employee verses 'the temp'. They care about their customers, their employees and doing the right thing. Strong ethics are paramount.  Employees are encouraged to take advantage of every opportunity and to give honest feedback. Ohio Health participates in many charitable events and encourages employees to participate as they choose.  There are a vast number of resources and benefits available at Ohio Health.  I cannot say enough about this company!
cons: I haven't seen or experienced anything negative.

review_title: A very good place to work
job_title: Information Services Business Relationship Manager in Schaumburg, IL
pros: In general they walk the talk about "employees are our greatest resource". Management is trained on a regular basis, there is annual opportunity for employee feedback, and HR policies and programs are designed to make the employee feel valued. There is focus on the patient and family to make them feel cared for and respected.
cons: Organization has expanded a lot in recent years, so there are growing pains incorporating more locations and personnel, some with different work habits and expectations. And there are some bad bosses - it's not perfect.

review_title: This is a company that actually cares. I'm really happy working for them!
job_title: Information Services Systems Analyst in Columbus, OH
pros:
- Our wages are more than fair and the benefits aren't bad either. 
- They are serious about embracing diversity, as evidenced by same-sex partner benefits and plenty of minorities in leadership positions. 
- The company is doing really well, both in profit and patient satisfaction. This gets paid forward to employees in the form of monetary bonuses to employees, random gift cards, free zoo days, and other little perks to show their appreciation... plus this obviously gives us some measure of job security. 
- From an IT perspective, I think they are doing the best they can for such a large organization. IT is employed by the company rather than out-sourced. They don't skimp on their technology standards, with the current standard being solid state hard drives and 4GB ram. Still, our docs are annoyed that we won't give everybody IPADs. :)
- It really does not seem hard to move up in this company. Maybe it varies somewhat based on your department, but I see people being promoted all the time. Personally, I was able to put in my time at entry level and work my way into exactly the sort of position I wanted. I didn't know anyone prior to being hired on and had no friends in high places. I just did my job well, volunteered when my boss or teammates needed help -- pretty basic formula for success. 
- OhioHealth jobs tend to be really stable, so if you're NOT interested in climbing political ladders and just want to come in and do what's expected of you and bring home a paycheck for your family, you can absolutely do that. I know people who have been in the same role for 10 or 15 years and are content to remain where they are. 
- Raises in this company are across the board rather than merit-based, so you're going to get your 3% increase regardless of how hard you work. Ambitious people may see this as a negative, but I think it's nice for overall morale and keeps backstabbing and rivalry to a minimum.
cons:
- Communication could be better, especially between departments They try, but sometimes the left hand doesn't know what the right is doing. Maybe it comes with being such a large organization.
- You will be expected to use the word "Systemness" often, and with a straight face. 
- This is not a great place to work if you can't cope with change. Healthcare and technology are hopelessly linked these days. Technology changes so quickly nowadays, and OhioHealth is determined to keep up.  A simple task like checking in patients or passing meds may be done in a completely different way than it was two or three years ago due to changes in technology,  If you can't handle regular changes to your workflow, this may not be the best place for you.
- We acquire smaller private practices and clinics all the time, and sometimes these associates have growing pains as we encourage them to...well... assimilate. Not that we're the Borg, but... OK, it's true. We're basically the Borg of Healthcare. 
- Our current Believe in WE marketing is super cheesy. The We People, or "Weeple", are plastered on posters throughout the hospitals and set as the desktop background on every computer. Get used to their cartoon eyes following you. 
- I'm having trouble thinking of any more serious cons. I'm really quite happy working here!

job_title: Digital Strategy Intern in Columbus, OH
pros:
As an intern with Talent Acquisition, I've been able to work on projects that appeal to my professional goals and I've been heavily connected to movers and shakers within my organization in the short time I've been in this role. 

Working as a Digital Strategy Intern, I've worked on an assortment of interesting projects. Within my department, I've helped redesign the Careers website, created digital recruitment strategies around hard-to-fill positions and educated fellow associates on digital branding efforts.

I've also been able to work on projects outside of Talent Acquisition as an intern. In my short time within the role, I've helped develop a mentorship program aimed to develop our associates professionally and I've contributed to an innovation program aimed to solve some of OhioHealth's challenge by utilizing the creativity and ingenuity of our associates.

I would heavily recommend working here at OhioHealth, whether you start as an intern or not. The people here are amazing -- clever, compassionate and motivated. By working in Talent Acquisition, I've had a family from day one who has supported me and encouraged my professional endeavors. I've also been able to network with individuals at OhioHealth who are leading their field and driving innovation. My mentors and peers are like friends and family who I will keep with me for the rest of my life.

So sad to leave, but happy to start my Master's program. I hope to work with OhioHealth again in the future.
cons:
Since OhioHealth is healthcare leader in the central Ohio market (we provide healthcare to 47 of the 88 counties in Ohio!), it is difficult for leadership to see the value in taking risks. OhioHealth achieved such success over the last 30 years by taking risks under the leadership of Dave Blom; however, now that we are "on top," it has been very difficult to continue to innovate and make sustainable, impactful progress. I have personally been a part of one of the most recent programs aimed to create innovative solutions that benefit OhioHealth and its mission to provide healthcare to our communities. I have heard the desire and need for innovation. Yet, when we finally have the opportunity to take initiative and drive innovation, most of us don't take the opportunity since we have a risk-averse culture. 

To stay ahead in the market as we move from Volume to Value (quantity of care to quality of care), we as a system need to change the way we perceive risk. We need to create a safe-to-fail environment at OhioHealth so that risk-taking, once again, becomes a part of our culture. This is how we are going to best serve our communities and provide the most advanced healthcare in Ohio and the nation.

pros: When correctly staffed with experienced employees, this place ran smoothly. There are or were some genuine good employees that worked hard, and were friendly. That was a small percentage though.
cons:
Worked in ED. Often short staffed, You could find yourself with two critically ill people and you would get new patients in the other two room, and have no idea but pray the don’t need you right then. ED nurses would have to transport very ill patients to far locations, sometimes alone. When you left no one had time to watch your rooms, and the patient you taking upstairs? That room has been filled with a new person as soon as you left the unit. They are  seen by the doc and you have a list of meds,ivs,blood draws to do before you make it back to assess your new patient.
This place has  SUPER CLIQUES, the charge RN are the same  people who stay having friendships with managers, and got the easy Jobs  to prove it, My first months I would leave utterly drained, and swear I would never come back. HCAHPS and Press Ganey scores impact all hospitals; however, the importance of these benchmarks have placed great amount of stress on all employees. pros: Good health insurance, it's very clear they care about their patients and about quality healthcare.  When you find the people you click with, you will build relationships that will last for the rest of your life.  The way they approach healthcare education is innovative and extremely effective.  They do seem to care about work-life balance.  If you are a healthcare worker, this can be a good place--but if not, the "healthcare culture" permeates into the other jobs and if you don't have the same types of priorities and thought processes of the typical healthcare employee, you will be constantly criticized and disrespected.
cons: It can be hard to find the people you click with.  There is a rampant lack of communication and teamwork.  If you are one of those people who likes to ask "why" you will be told you are too argumentative.  They have this rather unhealthy idea that their employees need to constantly strive to improve--improvement is great, but they do not take the time to celebrate the things a person does well.  Reviews are always focused on what could be better, and not what is good.  When I started out I felt ostracized by my team members.  This made me very depressed, so then I was constantly criticized for my attitude, rather than a single person asking what was wrong or trying to reach out to me.  When I finally started finding people I liked to work with and a job I liked to do, they fired me.  I was told that it was because I didn't fit my position, but with the contributions I clearly made in the time I was there, and the size of the company, I am dubious that there was no other position for me.

Numerous bosses and supervisors in several years, 70% turnover rate in several departments, including mine. HR reps were switched each 6 -8 months. Never seen anything like this in my entire career. Worst human beings I've ever been subjected to in my life. Leaders who lie through their teeth to associates' faces, discussing employees personal information with other leaders and employees, gossiping and outright lying about them to get them fired, setting employees up to fire them for no reason other than to ruin their reputation (OH is an at-will state; employers don't need a reason to let an employee go) - you name it - these practices exist throughout OhioHealth. And it's rampant. OH claims to continue to be listed in one of the Top 100 companies to work for, but the surveys the employees receive to fill out are SO skewed that there's no way to answer them in a way that doesn't paint OhioHealth in the best possible light, and there's also no place to add any kind negative of feedback; only positive feedback is accepted. In my several years of employment there, I spoke to scores of unhealthy, unhappy employees there. Multiple senior level leaders who were very good, honest, kind people who worked there for a number of years were either being forced out, severely demoted for embarrassing reasons (the real reasons were because they wouldn't go along with the slimy practices that had since become a daily routine there), and it was only getting uglier.

cons: After bringing a concern to HR that I believed someone was trying to sabotage my work by switching samples around, it continued to occur and I was ultimately fired for it. I did my part. I scanned and double checked names. But because I somehow made enemies with one of the MLT's, according to an inside source, this particular person hated me and wanted me gone. They got what they asked for and I have no way to prove my innocence. I'm left jobless and have had a hell of a time trying to convince any other potential employer that I'm worth employment. I've been on two interviews and both times have mysteriously been rejected after what seemed to be promising interviews. I can only assume my previous managers are behind it. My claims have fallen on deaf ears. No additional investigation was done at my request. Yes, I could take the issue to a lawyer, but at what cost to myself? Remember, I have no income right now. Going up against a wealthy bully like OhioHealth seems futile and not worth the effort in the end. It took 3 weeks for a coworker who was found to be stealing meds and medical equipment to get fired after multiple interviews with involved parties and a full company investigation into the matter, but I did not warrant the same benefits.
